./.title: Introduction
./.body:
react-redux-provide
 

This library aims to make it as quick and easy as possible to build applications with React and Redux.
It enforces a separation of concerns.  It keeps user interface decoupled from application state.  It keeps application state decoupled from data sources.
Build your UI with React.
Manage application state with Redux providers.
Persist and share application state with replication.
Use pure functions everywhere.
You can use this library to build applications of any size and complexity, for the real world or for fun.
Familiar with React and Redux (including react-redux)?  You can use your same tools and libraries.  Everything you've learned still applies.  You've probably recognized patterns when connecting Redux to your React components.  You've probably recognized patterns when optimizing updates for efficiency.  This library is an abstraction of these patterns.  By default, it minimizes boilerplate and maximizes efficiency.
Unfamiliar with React and/or Redux?  This library should hopefully still be easy for you to learn.  Simplicity is key when building software, and this library is as simple as it gets.
Next: Brief Overview

brief-overview.html.title: Brief Overview
brief-overview.html.body:
Brief Overview
We will be using the following throughout this library's documentation:

ECMAScript 2015 - Modern JavaScript.  The programming language used in every example.
JSX - A JavaScript syntax extension resembling XML, typically used with React.
React - A JavaScript library for building user interfaces (UI).
Redux - A JavaScript library for managing application state.

We will cover the basics of each as we go along, so if any of this is new to you, you may still understand everything.
This library revolves around three principles:

The UI should be as declarative as possible, a simple composition of components.  Ideally, each component is a pure, stateless function.  A pure, stateless function component will always render the same output when given the same input.  This enforces predictable, well-defined components.

The UI components should always specify the types of properties they use, as propTypes.  Components use these properties to render and/or update the application state.  A component's properties come from their parent component or a provider instance.  Provider instances exist within the context of the application.

Use any number of Redux stores to manage the state of any number of objects.  An object can represent a user, a document, anything.  A provider is a composition of functions and properties designed to manage these objects.  These functions and properties are specific to Redux - e.g., actions, reducers, etc.  You can have any number of instances of the same provider.  This helps enforce separation of concerns and reusability.
Note: Providers instantiate as React components need them.  Each provider instance has its own Redux store.  This store is automatically created based on the provider's properties.  You will almost never have to directly access the store.


Next: Core Example

core-example/.title: Core Example
core-example/.body:
Core Example
The concepts covered throughout this example are what you'll use the most.  This is what we're going to cover:

Managing the state of a single thing with a set of Redux actions and reducers.

Managing the state of more than one thing using the same set of Redux actions and reducers.

Persisting the state of each thing to a data source using replication.

Querying the data source for any thing matching some state.

Tying everything together in a way that maintains decoupling.


Let's get started!
Next: Managing Some "Thing"

core-example/managing-some-thing.html.title: Managing Some "Thing"

core-example/more-than-one-thing.html.title: More Than One "Thing"

core-example/persisting-state-via-replic.title: Persisting State via Replication

core-example/querying-replicated-states..title: Querying Replicated States

core-example/tying-everything-together.h.title: Tying Everything Together

extended-documentation/.title: Extended Documentation
extended-documentation/.body:
Extended Documentation
The extended documentation is a work in progress.  Real world examples of each section are coming soon!
Feel free to reach out with any questions or concerns.
If it's urgent, find timbur on the Reactiflux discord.
Next: What does this do?

extended-documentation/what-does-this-do.title: What does this do?
extended-documentation/what-does-this-do.body:
What does this do?

This library allows you to:

Build your applications in an extremely declarative manner.  Think of it as the Redux equivalent of GraphQL/Relay, but slightly easier to get started (you decide).

Share and manipulate application state across any number of components.  Updates are extremely efficient!  Check the comments in the source.

Think of provider-specific propTypes as any other import statement.  The only difference is that props are synchronized with the current state and obtained via context.  It's easiest to think about it like this: If a component isn't passed some propType as a prop, it will be automatically provided to it via context from the matching provider.

Save, restore, and replicate the state of anything within your application.  Providers can be used to represent and manage anything!  Users, pages, themes, posts, comments, votes, maps, etc., etc., etc.  The only limit is your imagination.

Use multiple Redux stores.  Why multiple stores?  This allows for a maximum separation of concerns while also making it possible to (re)use providers when manipulating the state of multiple provider instances of the same type (e.g., users).

Compose many different actions, reducers, etc., into a single provider.

Compose many small applications and/or services into a single application.

Maximally separate your concerns, which leads to fewer bugs and a better experience for developers.

Eliminates the need for any extraneous dependencies within components, which makes all components and providers instantly distributable and reusable.  Components get the relevant Redux stores' states and action creators as props via React's context.

Hot reload your providers in development with no extra configuration.


Next: What is a provider?

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: What is a provider?
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
What is a provider?
If you're already familiar with Redux's Provider component, that's not what this is, but it's where the inspiration came from.  A provider can do essentially anything Redux can do, but it is encapsulated, reusable, extremely declarative, and mostly automatic.
For example, you might have a theme provider and a user provider.  These providers are automatically instantiated as needed, so in the case of the user provider, you can have many different instances at the same time to represent multiple users.  Each instance has its own "store" and works completely independently of one another, but you can also configure providers to automatically subscribe to and/or find/create/interact with others if necessary.  "Stores" are responsible for holding the current state and handling actions to update that state.  The current state and action creators (and any props which might be derived from a combination of state and component props) are automatically mapped to React components as needed.
A provider is a plain object composed of a handful of different properties (see below).  These properties are designed to work together to represent and manipulate the state of anything within your application.  You can also declaratively replicate the state of any provider instance's store to some database and/or to other clients.  Redux stores are automatically created based on these properties and assigned to each provider instance.
Example:
export default {
  // the basics
  actions: { ... },
  reducers: { ... },
  merge: { ... },             // optional
  middleware: [ ... ],        // optional
  enhancer: () => {},         // optional

  // initialization
  state: { ... },             // optional, typically set via app config
  onInstantiated: () => {},   // optional, sometimes set via app config
  onReady: () => {},          // optional, sometimes set via app config

  // replication
  key: () => {},              // optional, typically set via app config
  replication: { ... },       // optional, typically set via app config
  clientStateKeys: [ ... ],   // optional, sometimes set via app config

  // advanced
  subscribeTo: { ... },       // optional, typically set via app config
  subscribers: { ... },       // optional, typically set via app config
  wait: () => {},             // optional, typically set via app config
  clear: () => {},            // optional, typically set via app config
  isGlobal: Boolean           // optional, typically set via app config
};

Next: The basics

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: The basics
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
The basics
For the most part, your providers will only ever be composed of actions, reducers, and the occasional merge functions.  You can also include middleware and/or a enhancer if you need something out of the ordinary.
Next: actions

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: actions
reducers
merge
middleware
enhancer
Initialization
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
Initialization
Provider instantiation occurs on an as-needed basis.  Each provider goes through the same initialization process, which depends on the provider instance's key.
Next: key

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: key
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
key
Optional string or function.  Defaults to its respective key within the providers object.  See the example below for more about the providers object.
Providers are instantiated based on their key:

If the key is a string, it's considered a static provider and is instantiated immediately at the top level.  This key becomes the provider instance's identifying providerKey.

If the key is a function, it's considered a dynamic provider and is instantiated only as needed.  The function should accept some component instance as an argument and should return a string which becomes the provider instance's identifying providerKey.  If a provider instance with that providerKey already exists, the same instance will be used.  The function may also return a falsy value, which will disable replication for the instance and the providerKey will default to its respective key within the providers object.


Note: Replication won't work without a key, since a falsy value indicates disabled replication.
Example:
providers.user.key = ({ props }) => props.userId
  ? `userId=${props.userId}`
  : null;

Next: defaultKey

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: defaultKey
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
defaultKey
The provider instance's key will default to this.  You typically don't need to set this yourself since it will come from the providers object.
Next: state

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: state
onInstantiated
onReady
Replication
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
Replication
Replication is a key concept when building any stateful application where you need to store, retrieve, and/or share information.  When implemented correctly, it allows you to decouple data initialization, storage, and retrieval from your application so that your only concern is rendering its state.  It allows you declaratively connect application state to data sources and create efficient, scalable, and reliable software with relatively minimal effort.  It allows you to instantly swap one database for another, one websocket implementation for another, or any other use case you can think of.  If you're unfamiliar with replication, Wikipedia's State machine replication page is a good place to start!
Creating replicators for Redux and using them with providers should hopefully be pretty straightforward.  Similar to providers, a replicator is a plain object with a few optional properties that describe how the state should be initialized and/or replicated - i.e., stored within a database or sent to other clients via websockets.
Next: replication

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: replication
baseQuery
baseQueryOptions
clientStateKeys
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
clientStateKeys
Optional array of reducerKeys.  This isn't used directly by react-redux-provide, but it is the recommended way to specify which reducerKeys should be sent to the client by the server.  See provide-page for an example of how this is used.
Next: Advanced

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: Advanced
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
Advanced
This section is for advanced provider properties which are used only under special circumstances.
Next: subscribeTo

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: subscribeTo
subscribers
wait
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
wait
Optional function that is called whenever a provider instance begins doing something asynchronously.  This is used in conjunction with the clear property.
Next: clear

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: clear
isGlobal
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
isGlobal
Optional boolean value.  Useful for cases where you want to use the same provider instances across multiple requests on the server.  An example of this is an ID generator provider which needs an atomic store.
Next: Thunk Api

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: Thunk API
getInstance
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
getInstance
getInstance (Object|String state|key|providerKey, Function callback)
Uses instantiateProvider to get some provider instance based on some state - i.e., same method used when providing some instance to components.
Next: getInstances

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: getInstances
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
getInstances
getInstances (Array states|keys|providerKeys, Function callback)
A shortcut to get multiple instances at once.  Uses getInstance under the hood.
Next: createInstance

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: createInstance
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
createInstance
createInstance (Object state, Function callback)
Just like getInstance but ensures the initial states are replicated.
Next: createInstances

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: createInstances
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
createInstances
createInstances (Array states, Function callback)
A shortcut to create multiple instances at once.
Next: setStates

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: setStates
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
setStates
setStates (Object states)
This should typically only be used client-side when the server sends the client states that it needs to properly perform some action.  This function sets the states of multiple provider instances, or if they don't exist yet, their states are cached on the window.clientStates object.
If you're using the official page provider, you won't ever need to use this function yourself.  See the getPageStates and submitForm methods in provide-page/src/index.js for exact usage.
Next: Find

extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.title: find
extended-documentation/what-is-a-provide.body:
find
find (Object state, Optional Boolean doInstantiate, Function callback)
Queries replicators with a handleQuery method to retrieve an array of states representing any provider instance partially matching the state argument.  If doInstantiate is true, providers will be instantiated based on each state and passed to the callback.  If doInstantiate is false or omitted, only the array of states is passed to the callback.
Next: Contextual component props

extended-documentation/contextual-compon.title: Contextual component props
extended-documentation/contextual-compon.body:
Contextual component props
These properties are passed down via context and are used interally by this library.  You can override them with your own props at any time, but in most cases you should never have to do that.
Next: providers

extended-documentation/contextual-compon.title: providers
extended-documentation/contextual-compon.body:
providers
Object containing all of the providers used throughout the app.  The top level component should receive this prop.  You can also pass a new providers object (along with a new providerInstances object) at any level, but you typically shouldn't do that.
Next: providerInstances

extended-documentation/contextual-compon.title: providerInstances
extended-documentation/contextual-compon.body:
providerInstances
Object containing all of the instantiated providers.
Next: activeQueries

extended-documentation/contextual-compon.title: activeQueries
extended-documentation/contextual-compon.body:
activeQueries
Object containing any queries being handled at the time.
Next: queryResults

extended-documentation/contextual-compon.title: queryResults
extended-documentation/contextual-compon.body:
queryResults
Object containing the latest query results.
Next: Query-related-component-props

extended-documentation/query-related-com.title: Query-related component props
extended-documentation/query-related-com.body:
Query-related component props
There are a handful of props you can use for finding provider instances whose states have been replicated to (stored within) data sources.
Next: query

extended-documentation/query-related-com.title: query
queryOptions
extended-documentation/query-related-com.body:
queryOptions
Only used in conjunction with a valid query.  These options are passed to your replicator's handleQuery function and should typically be specific to the options supported by the replicator.
Coming soon: A standard/recommended set of query options that replicators should support.  Please see https://github.com/loggur/react-redux-provide/issues/33 and discuss!
Next: result

extended-documentation/query-related-com.title: result
extended-documentation/query-related-com.body:
result
Only used in conjunction with a valid query.  The result returned by your replicator's handleQuery function.  Defaults to null.  Only exists if the query prop exists.
Next: queries

extended-documentation/query-related-com.title: queries
queriesOptions
extended-documentation/query-related-com.body:
queriesOptions
Only used in conjunction with a valid queries.  Works exactly like queryOptions but with the options pre-mapped to each provider.
Next: results

extended-documentation/query-related-com.title: results
extended-documentation/query-related-com.body:
results
Only used in conjunction with a valid queries.  See queries example above.  Only exists if the queries prop exists.
Next: Store modifications

extended-documentation/store-modificatio.title: Store modifications
extended-documentation/store-modificatio.body:
Store modifications
Providers and replication enhances the store object, adding a few useful properties and methods to it.
store.key
The current key.
store.setKey (String key, Function readyCallback)
Sets the current key.  The readyCallback is called after all of the replicators have fully initialized based on the new key.
store.setState (Mixed nextState)
You typically shouldn't need to use this, as state changes should almost always occur as a result of store.dispatch(action).  But it may be useful for keeping a store's state synchronized with some data source which doesn't rely on actions.  If using reducerKeys, the nextState is expected to be an object and is merged into the current state, similar to React's setState.  If not using reducerKeys, the nextState replaces the current state entirely.
store.watch (String reducerKey, Function handler)
Mostly used internally for watching for whenever some reducer returns a different state so that components can efficiently know when they should update.
store.onReady (Function readyCallback)
You can use this if you know your replicator(s) asynchronously initialize the store's state and would like to do something immediately after initialization.  The readyCallback will receive the store within an object - e.g., readyCallback({ store }).
store.initializedReplication
If for some reason you need to know whether or not getInitialState has completed, you can check this boolean property.  It will be true after initialization.
Next: Counter Example

extended-documentation/counter-example.h.title: Counter example
